docs.lead_paragraph: The rich grew richer in New York and the poor over all remained poor, according to census figures released today, resulting in the widest income gap of any major metropolitan area in the country.The top fifth of earners in 2005 made nearly 20 times what the bottom fifth earned in the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut metropolitan region. In Manhattan, the disparity was a chasm, with the wealthiest making nearly 40 times more than the poorest -- $351,333 compared to $8,855, or a bigger gap than in any county in the county.

headline.main: Census: New York Region Has Widest Income Gap

docs.abstract: Income inequality was greater in Manhattan than in any other county in the country in 2006.
docs.snippet: Income inequality was greater in Manhattan than in any other county in the country in 2006.

docs.snippet: Readers respond to Bob Herbert's Aug. 28 column, "Holding Kids Hostage." Michelle L., Bastrop, Tex.: On and on about the CHIP program and the issue of what makes a family eligible to qualify for it. Let's talk about universal health care for all....

docs.lead_paragraph: The city's decision yesterday to discipline three Fire Department officers in the wake of the Deutsche Bank fire dominates local news coverage today. With the continuing revelations about malfunctioning equipment, inadequate fire plans and careless actions by contractors, the public pressure for answers continues to mount.In an overview, Al Baker notes that fire union officials criticized the decision to remove the officers from their command; some critics have started to call for the resignation of the fire commissioner, Nicholas Scoppetta. Meanwhile, the district attorney's investigation into the case continues. An accompanying article by John Sullivan notes that the inspection system was revamped after seven people died in a Harlem apartment fire in 1987. But the scale of the work involved, with New York's dense network of buildings, is daunting. Firefighters conduct general inspections while civilians perform reviews of critical systems like sprinklers. The number of inspections by fire companies fell sharply between the 2005 and 2006 fiscal years, for reasons that are not clear.

headline.main: Morning Buzz: Fallout From Fire, Man Suspected in Multiple Killings, Ground Zero Asthma and More

docs.abstract: A roundup of the morning news.
docs.snippet: A roundup of the morning news.

docs.lead_paragraph: For President Bush, the back-to-back resignations of two longtime aides amount to a political housecleaning for his last months in office.

docs.lead_paragraph: An article on Aug. 20 about the Church of San Clemente in Pisco, Peru, which was the deadliest spot in the recent powerful earthquake there, misidentified the denomination of the church. It is Roman Catholic, not Eastern Orthodox. The article also misidentified the patron saint of the parish. He was San Clemente Romano, or St. Clement, not St. Vincent de Paul. (The Vincentian Fathers administer the parish.).

docs.lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an editorial on Sunday misstated a new rule governing the expansion of the State Children’s Health Insurance Program. States must show that they have enrolled 95 percent of the children in families with incomes below 200 percent of the poverty level before they can extend the limit above 250 percent, not to 250 percent.

docs.lead_paragraph: The strange circumstances of the campaign that allowed Zack Space to replace Ohio Republican Bob Ney in Congress has Republicans spoiling for a rematch.

docs.lead_paragraph: Zack Space, who was elected after Bob Ney pleaded guilty to accepting bribes from the lobbyist Jack Abramoff, has been declared one of the Republican Party’s top targets for 2008.
